column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column7:
Key findings from the assessment include:
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ The financial impact of physical climate risk in the store network is not materially significant in the context of ColesÃ¢ÂÂ total portfolio, which is well diversified across assets and regions. In addition, concerning store design, the specifications already consider future conditions to improve resilience in extreme weather (for example, new stores are designed for a one-in-100-year storm event). The design brief is frequently updated.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Flooding events drive approximately 60% of financial losses across the portfolio. The financial impact of flooding events is estimated to increase by around 23% over the next 10 years when assessing against RCP 8.5 2030 (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change high-emissions scenario).
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ The distribution network (distribution centres and transport routes) was found to be the area of highest risk due to the scale of potential downstream impacts. Therefore, the distribution network's resilience is a critical consideration in all operations and future asset planning.
Ã¢ÂÂ¢ Coles highly relies on asset integrity and the function of third-party assets, such as transport
infrastructure, distribution centres and shopping centres. In FY24, we will use these findings to
inform our climate risk management approach.

column6: Financial assistance received from government
column7: No material financial assistance was identified.

column6: Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
column7: For the significant proportion of Coles team members, their base pay rate is set by the relevant enterprise agreement (referred to in GRI 2-30). The individual team members' classification and employment category determine their applicable pay rate. For appropriate industrial instruments governing employment conditions for Coles team members, the annual minimum wage rates ordered by the Fair Work Commission and proper award reference instruments are considered reference points.

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column7: Coles conducts risk assessments across its operations, and investigations are commenced where required. Due diligence checks and independent audits are conducted on suppliers as part of our Ethical Sourcing Program.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column7: Coles has a suite of governance policies, including our Code of Conduct, Anti-Bribery Policy, Political Donations Policy and Whistleblower Policy, designed to create a culture of acting lawfully and ethically. Our Whistleblowing service is available 24 hours a day. Our policies are accessible online, and we provide relevant personnel Anti-Bribery and Corruption training annually.

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: There were no confirmed incidents of corruption by Coles Group or its team members under our Anti-Bribery Policy during the reporting period.

column6: Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
column7: No legal action was taken during the reporting period for anti-competitive behaviour, anti-trust or monopoly practices by Coles Group or its employees.

column6: Reduction of energy consumption
column13: Building on work undertaken over the past three years to align our approach with the 2017 recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures, this year, we commenced the development of a Climate Action Roadmap (Ã¢ÂÂthe RoadmapÃ¢ÂÂ). The Roadmap is anticipated to include critical actions for Coles over the short, medium, and long term to effectively manage climate-related risks and opportunities and respond to stakeholder expectations.
column20: Task Force on Climate-Relted Financial Disclosure, Climate Action Roadmap, Risks and Opportunities

column6: Reduction of energy consumption
column13: Coles is a significant energy user and producer of greenhouse gas emissions, directly in our operations and indirectly through our extensive supply chains. We are committed to increasing resource efficiency and reducing emissions in areas we control and influence.
column20: Greenhouse Gas Emissions, Extensive Supply Chains, Resource Efficiency

column6: Reduction of energy consumption
column13: Following the successful pilot of the Corporate Emissions Reduction Transparency (CERT) report, codesigned by the Clean Energy Regulator and industry, in 2022, Coles continued participating in and promoting the CERT report. The 2023 submission has evolved further and helps encourage emissions reductions in Australia by allowing companies to set emissions reduction targets and track progress using verified data held by the CER.
column20: Corporate Emissions Reduction Transparency (CERT), Clean Energy Regulator, Emissions Reduction
